Lack of evidence: The expert's verdict highlights that there is no evidence to suggest that the Nashville bombing was election-related or an attempt to stop an AT&T audit into Dominion software and cover up election corruption.
Denial from companies involved: Both AT&T and Dominion have denied the claims made in the posts circulating online. They have stated that there was no such audit conducted by AT&T and that Dominion's machines were not recently transported to Nashville.
Baseless conspiracy theory: The expert's verdict identifies the claim as a baseless conspiracy theory that started circulating online after the Christmas morning explosion. It suggests that the bombing was an attempt to stop the alleged audit and cover up voter fraud.
Confirmation from authorities: The FBI confirmed that a man named Anthony Warner was responsible for the bombing and was killed in the blast. They also stated that the bomb was located in a recreational vehicle owned by Warner. This confirmation adds to the evidence against the claim made in the posts.
